description: From Portuguese pagode, which is via Malayalam പകോതി (pakōti) from Sanskrit भगवती (bhagavatī, name of a goddess) or भागवत (bhāgavata, “follower of Bhagavatī”).

entries.meaning: A religious building in South and Southeast Asia, especially a multi-storey tower erected as a Hindu or Buddhist temple. [from 16th c.]
(now rare, usually in form pagod) An image or carving of a god in South and Southeast Asia; an idol. [from 16th c.]
(now historical) A unit of currency, a coin made of gold or half gold, issued by various dynasties in medieval southern India. [from 16th c.]
examples: I, in about two hours, notwithstanding the utmost caution, found myself minus upwards of six hundred pagodas  […] .

entries.meaning: An ornamental structure imitating the design of the religious building, erected in a park or garden. [from 18th c.]
